I'm still on the fence regarding building long running services and complete applications on top of FaaS platforms
I see FaaS platforms as scripting engines for service providers. Functions become the glue between managed services.
Typed events combined with simple functions to process them is a huge win and why FaaS platforms are the perfect complement to containers.

text: @williamsjoe Yes. How you package and execute a process can easily be decoupled from how you charge for it.

@tjholowaychuk I'm talking containers as a way to package code and define an entrypoint. It's up to the Serverless platform to execute it.
Serverless should be about on demand execute of a process in response to events with a pricing model to match. Build service
FaaS seems like an evolution of Heroku buildpacks with even more limitations.
All these FaaS offerings are basically trying to couple a build service with an execution model.
You can launch containers on demand and provide the same interface and pricing model

The silent conversation was interrupted by the horns from the drivers behind waiting to pass. We parted ways as better people.
I never thought of it that way.
column5: as he wiped away the tear.

text: My eyes started to water
column4: both of us were to macho to cry
column5: but embraced the moment as a sign of mutual respect.

text: As he slowly turned towards me
column4: he removed his glasses now wet from the single tear trapped underneath.

text: We're at the entrance now
column4: but I'm still in the car. Another few moments would pass before the driver turned around.

text: They got your attention, now ask yourself: are you more upset about the style of protest or the issue being protested
I asked him: "Think about it
column4: what good is a protest if it does not get people's attention?". He took pause.

text: We're at the airport now but there's a bit of traffic between us and my terminal; just enough time for closing remarks.
Strong words
column4: but we're not arguing. We took turns making our points and sharing our perspectives.

text: It's called a protest
column6: and our country. It just makes me mad as hell"

text: At this point I realized I've yet to have this debate out loud. I was not prepared. But somehow I found the right words.
I could see his eyes in the rearview mirror eagerly awaiting my response.
My first thought was to be like: "Excuse me?"
column4: and then proceed to tell him why he was wrong
column5: but I chose a different route.

text: He had a deep anger in his face. This was pent up emotion which he decided to set free.
What do you think about all these black NFL players disrespecting the flag?. Yeah he went there.
Yeah
column5: where the hell is this going? And yeah
column6: I'm still out of walking distance from the airport.

text: You seem like a smart guy
column4: he said. "You're a young black man who seems to have his head on straight"

text: We're 30 minutes into the conversation; I had some how passed his test. He let his guard down
column4: and took the conversation in a new direction.

text: In many ways I feel like I'm representing all black people and this one conversation would have way more impact than it should.
This is the point where I get really conscious about how I speak. I go out of my way to avoid confirming any negative stereotypes.
So what do you do for Google?
We were different in almost every way. He was tall with a slender frame and reminded me of my uncle; only difference
I grabbed a quick glance at my phone hoping to gain some insight into the person I was talking too.
This was his way of breaking the ice.
We slowly pulled out of the parking lot. He lowered the music. "So you must work for Google?". I think the t-shirt gave it away.
Where you going?
column5: I responded. I was in for a 45 minute ride; maybe an hour with traffic.

text: He picked me up from the Google campus. I was wearing my Google t-shirt with my work badge in plain sight.
People can change and if you're patient you'll get to watch it happen.
